article.title: On the isotope effect in compressed superconducting H$_\textrm 3$S and D$_\textrm 3$S

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure shows the transition temperatures (Tc) for H3S and D3S versus applied pressure (P) alongside their residual resistance ratios (RRR). What is the main observation regarding the relationship between Tc and RRR for both H3S and D3S?
choices: Tc and RRR show an inverse correlation, where higher Tc values correspond to lower RRR values.
There is no clear correlation between Tc and RRR for either H3S or D3S.
Tc and RRR exhibit a positive correlation, with higher Tc values coinciding with higher RRR values.
Tc remains relatively constant regardless of changes in RRR for both H3S and D3S.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure plots the residual resistance ratio (RRR) against the fractional transition width (∆Tc/Tc) for H3S and D3S samples. What does the trend indicated by the dashed line suggest about the relationship between sample quality and the superconducting transition?
choices: Higher sample quality, indicated by higher RRR, is associated with a sharper (narrower) superconducting transition.
Lower sample quality, indicated by lower RRR, leads to a sharper (narrower) superconducting transition.
There is no clear correlation between sample quality (RRR) and the sharpness of the superconducting transition.
The data for H3S and D3S shows opposite trends, indicating different mechanisms governing the superconducting transition.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure illustrates the relationship between transition temperature (Tc) and residual resistance ratio (RRR) for H3S and D3S samples. What significant conclusion can be drawn from the data points highlighted with dot fills (corresponding to P ≥ Pm)?
choices: There is a positive correlation between Tc and RRR for both H3S and D3S, with D3S consistently showing lower Tc values for similar RRR compared to H3S.
The data for H3S and D3S overlap completely, suggesting no significant difference in their superconducting behavior despite the isotope difference.
There is an inverse relationship between Tc and RRR for both H3S and D3S, indicating a detrimental effect of higher sample quality on Tc.
The highlighted data points do not offer any conclusive evidence about the relationship between Tc and RRR for H3S and D3S.

multiple_choice_question.text: This figure depicts the calculated mass isotope effect exponent (α) as a function of applied pressure (P) for H3S and D3S. What is the significance of comparing the results obtained with different Poffset values in panels (a) and (b)?
choices: The comparison helps to evaluate the influence of varying sample quality on the calculated α, particularly at low pressures.
The different Poffset values have no significant impact on the calculated α, indicating a robust isotope effect independent of pressure or sample quality.
Panel (a) represents a more accurate representation of the isotope effect compared to panel (b), as it uses the directly measured Tc values.
Panel (b) provides a more reliable estimation of the isotope effect, as it considers the potential influence of pressure on the superconducting transition.
